perturbation.original_text: The Bank is a member in good standing of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Pittsburgh; the deposit accounts of the Bank are insured by the FDIC up to the applicable limits.
perturbation.changed_text: The Bank is a member in good standing of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Pittsburgh.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the FDIC insurance clause creates a legal contradiction by omitting a legally mandated consumer protection related to deposit insurance. Federal law requires banks to disclose FDIC insurance, so omitting this statement is misleading.
perturbation.law_explanation: This act mandates deposit insurance and requires banks to disclose their insured status. Omitting the statement about FDIC insurance contradicts this requirement, potentially misleading depositors about the safety of their funds.

perturbation.original_text: Appropriate arrangements for placing the funds received from subscriptions for Securities or other offers to purchase Securities in special interest-bearing accounts with the Bank until all Securities are sold and paid for were made prior to the commencement of the Subscription Offering, with provision for refund to the purchasers as set forth above, or for delivery to the Company if all Securities are sold.
perturbation.changed_text: Arrangements for placing the funds received from subscriptions for Securities or other offers to purchase Securities in accounts with the Bank until all Securities are sold and paid for were made prior to the commencement of the Subscription Offering.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause 'special interest-bearing accounts' and 'with provision for refund to the purchasers as set forth above' creates a legal contradiction with consumer protection laws relating to refunds and proper management of investor funds. It is no longer clear if there is any investor protection.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Securities Act of 1933 and state-level securities regulations
perturbation.law_explanation: Securities laws require proper management of investor funds, especially during offerings. Removing the guaranteed refund clause makes this offering non-compliant.

perturbation.original_text: In addition to the reimbursement of the expenses specified in Section 4 hereof, the Agent will receive the following compensation for its services hereunder: (a) One percent (1.00%) of the aggregate purchase price of the Securities sold in the Subscription and Community Offering, excluding in each case shares purchased by (i) any employee benefit plan of the Company or the Bank established for the benefit of their respective directors, officers and employees, and (ii) any director, officer or employee of the Company or the Bank or members of their immediate families (which term shall mean parents, grandparents, spouse, siblings, children and grandchildren); and (b) With respect to any Securities sold by a National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. ("NASD") member firm (other than Sandler O'Neill) in the Syndicated Community Offering, (i) the compensation payable to Selected Dealers, (ii) any sponsoring dealer's fees; and (iii) a management fee to Sandler O'Neill of one percent (1.0 %) of the aggregate purchase price of the Securities sold in the Syndicated Community Offering. Any fees payable to Sandler O'Neill for Securities sold by Sandler O'Neill under any such agreement shall be limited to an aggregate of six percent (6.0 %) of the purchase price of the Securities sold by Sandler O'Neill and other NASD member firms.
perturbation.changed_text: In addition to the reimbursement of the expenses specified in Section 4 hereof, the Agent will receive compensation for its services hereunder as determined by the Company.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the specifics about the Agent's compensation, particularly the percentage-based fees, removes transparency. Such omissions can violate regulations requiring clear and upfront disclosure of fees associated with securities offerings.
perturbation.law_explanation: This act requires disclosures to prevent misleading information. Removing the compensation details can be seen as a way of not disclosing information.
